title: 109_hr1137
content: The Act may be cited as the "Responding Equitably, Swiftly, Proportionally, and On-time to Natural Disasters Act of 2005". The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to ensure that Federal assistance is adequate and maintains individuals' quality of life similar to before a disaster. It also aims to provide equitable assistance to minority, low-income individuals, households, and underserved communities. SEC. 3. REIMBURSEMENT FOR DEBRIS REMOVAL IN PRIVATE COMMUNITIES. Reimbursement for debris removal on private lands and communities under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include eligibility criteria for state or local governments providing services such as road maintenance, public safety, and garbage removal. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act now allows reimbursement for debris removal on private lands in communities if failure to remove debris puts lives at immediate risk. This applies to disaster declarations issued on or after August 11, 2004. Improving individual and household assistance. Amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act allows individuals or households affected by a major disaster to apply for assistance for 18 months, extendable by the President under extraordinary circumstances. Additionally, there is an increase in individual and household assistance by 25%. Amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act includes adjustments to fair market rent percentages and monetary limits for assistance. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to improve coordination and response efforts at local emergency operations centers by designating a local coordinating officer per affected county during a major disaster. SEC. 6. USE OF FEDERAL EMPLOYEES IN DETERMINING AND ADMINISTERING FEDERAL DISASTER ASSISTANCE. Section 307 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to specify that only employees of the Department of Homeland Security or other appropriate Federal agencies can allocate, distribute, or approve Federal financial assistance. The Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Emergency Preparedness and Response is required to prepare a report on the role and effectiveness of private organizations in administering Federal emergency disaster assistance. The Under Secretary of Homeland Security must prepare a report on private organizations' administration of disaster assistance, including audits. The report must be submitted to specific congressional committees within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 7. DISASTER EXPERT PROGRAM. This section authorizes the Disaster Expert Program under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Emergency Preparedness and Response will establish a disaster expert grant program on a competitive basis. Grants will be used to establish and maintain a disaster strike force team and provide disaster response training for team members. The Under Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a grant program for disaster experts to form a strike force team and provide training. Grants will be given to local governments and Indian tribes with experience in coordinating disaster assistance. The Under Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a grant program for disaster experts to form a strike force team and provide training. Grants will be given to local governments and Indian tribes to help them respond to natural disasters within their communities. The Federal share of the grant cost will be 100 percent, with up to 5 percent allowed for administrative expenses. Regulations for the program will be issued within 120 days, and funds will be authorized for appropriation. Authorization of $5,000,000 annually for disaster response training from 2006 to 2012.
